entry.title: Combined summary - Large-blocks and censorship
entry.summary: The issue of censorship resistance in the context of blockchain transactions is a topic that has been discussed by several experts in the field. There are concerns that the ability to start a new pool is diminishing, and that there are no clever technical solutions to avoid censorship if validating nodes and mining pools are centralized. One potential solution that has been proposed is to implement strongly limited block sizes, which would give individual users more control over their own transactions and prevent a single entity from gaining too much power.In support of this argument, the author cites several examples of governments and other organizations attempting to censor or restrict access to particular transactions. By implementing smaller block sizes, the author posits that users could ensure their transactions remain anonymous and free from interference. They also note that a decentralized network with limited block sizes would be less vulnerable to attacks from malicious actors seeking to undermine the system.Despite these concerns about censorship, a high number of validating nodes makes discouraging unwanted traffic difficult, indicating strong censorship resistance in Bitcoin. Nonetheless, the community emphasizes the need to maintain the ability to transfer value freely through economic incentives to find ways to move value between all off-chain transaction systems regardless of imposed restrictions.Other potential solutions to the issue of censorship resistance include auditable off-chain transaction systems and the use of UTXO merkle-sum-fee-trees and fraud notices to enable SPV nodes to reject invalid blocks without requiring the entire blockchain data. While various technical solutions have been proposed, none seem to be foolproof.The importance of preserving privacy when using Bitcoin to avoid being censored by miners is also emphasized. Another paper on providing Chaum-style privacy integrated with Bitcoin using zero knowledge proofs has been reviewed, but the technique is too slow and complicated to integrate practically. The idea of regulating miners to freeze certain outputs was proposed two years ago, but it was concluded that it was not a real risk since mining and transactions can be done anonymously.Overall, the discussions revolve around the importance of preserving privacy and censorship resistance in Bitcoin, especially in the face of scaling. While various technical solutions have been proposed, none seem to be foolproof. Nonetheless, the community emphasizes the need to maintain the ability to transfer value freely through economic incentives to find ways to move value between all off-chain transaction systems regardless of imposed restrictions.
